Dear Ms. Canales:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are sleeping during shifts and not performing appropriate
check-in's on youth.
Investigation The complainant was anonymous.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Supervisor denied staff are sleeping on shift or
not performing appropriate checks on youth. Supervisor stated
staff have been curled up on the couch with a blanket watching a
movie with the youths but not sleeping.
Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023, and October 5, 2023. Director reported while
reviewing video footage on 9/18/23 from 9/15/23 Staff 5 was
observed sleeping during third shift. Director reported Staff 5 was
terminated. Director denied seeing any other staff sleeping when
reviewing video footage.
Youth A and Youth F were interviewed face to face at the
facility on October 4, 2023, separately. They both denied being
aware of any staff sleeping while on shift. Youth A reported Staff
5 was fired for being on her laptop and not doing checks on the
youth.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth B stated Staff 3 sometimes sleeps on
third shift. Youth B reported she has seen Staff 3’s eyes closed
when Youth B has gotten up to use the bathroom. Youth B stated
Staff 3 talks to her when she gets up to use the bathroom. Youth
B described Staff 3 using the flashlight to do room checks “like
every 5 minutes.”
2

Staff 1 and Staff 2 were interviewed face to face at the facility
on October 4, 2023, separately. They both denied ever sleeping
while being on shift and reported they do not work third shift.
They both denied ever seeing any staff sleep while on shift or not
completing checks on youth.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth C stated she heard from other youth
Staff 1 and Staff 3 have slept while on shift. Youth C could not
recall what youths have said Staff 1 and Staff 3 were sleeping.
Youth C reported she has not seen any staff sleeping while on
shift or not checking on youths.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth D reported she has seen Supervisor and
Staff 1 sit on the couch during shifts and have their eyes closed.
Youth D stated she does not know if they were sleeping or just
“resting their eyes.” Youth D stated they were like that for five
minutes or less. Youth D stated Supervisor looked like he was
sleeping one time while at church with the youth. Youth D reported
staff “constantly check on us” at night with a flashlight.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth E described seeing Staff 6 asleep during
third shift when Youth E got up to use the bathroom. Staff 6
stated it was in the middle of the night and she could hear Staff 6
snoring. Youth E could not recall when this occurred.
AFA was interviewed via telephone on October 6, 2023. AFA
stated she never witnessed any staff sleeping while on shift when
doing video review. AFA reported some youth reported
Supervisor and Staff 1 were sitting on the couch sleeping but
camera showed Supervisor and Staff 1 talking to each other and
up and around moving. AFA stated different staff members have
received coaching notes to be more interactive with the youth
during shifts.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on October 10, 2023.
Staff 3 denied ever sleeping while on shift. Staff 3 reported
completing regular checks on the youth.
Video Reviewed:
Video from 9/29/23, 9/30/23, 10/01/23, and 10/02/23 reviewed at
various times throughout second and third shifts. None of the
3

video watched showed staff sleeping during shifts and not
performing checks.
Documents Reviewed:
• Bedtime log sheets from 9/17/23 -10/02/23: logs show
checks were being completed in variable interval checks
not exceeding 15 minutes.
• Supervisor’s personnel file: 9/09/23 write up for being
observed sitting on the couch with no movement and not
checking youth two separate times during third shift.
• Staff 5’s personnel file: Employee Separation report, “On
9/15/2023, at approximately 5:29am, video reviewed…Staff
5 was seen asleep while on post.” Staff 5 terminated from
facility on 9/16/2023.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Director reported Staff 5
was observed sleeping during third shift. A write up in
Supervisor’s personnel file indicated through video review it was
observed he was sleeping on third shift.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SI2023C0116001 dated 10/19/22; CAP approved 11/02/2022
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff talk on the phone, use air pods during shifts, and speak to
youth inappropriately. A staff member bought alcohol and drove
youth under the influence.
Investigation Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Supervisor stated staff were using their phones
on shift months ago and it was addressed. Supervisor stated
different staff members got written up. Supervisor denied it being
an issue anymore. Supervisor talked with staff about talking
negatively to one another. Supervisor stated the comments are
staff talking to one another about being tired of the youths’
behaviors or saying, “why do they always have to do that.”
Supervisor reported he has never heard staff make those
comments to youth, but youth may overhear staff talking to one
another. Supervisor stated he has pulled Staff 3 to the side in the
past and reminded her to take five minutes away from the youth
because she was upset.
4

Supervisor denied purchasing alcohol while on an outing with
youth. Supervisor stated he has bought snacks for youth and staff
when they are going on outings. Supervisor reported he has
never seen any staff purchase alcohol or drive under the
influence. Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the
facility on October 5, 2023. Supervisor denied Youth A ever
telling him Staff 3 smelled like marijuana or writing Staff 3 up for
smelling like marijuana. Supervisor stated he has not heard from
any youth about staff smelling like marijuana.
Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Director denied having any knowledge of staff
purchasing alcohol and driving youth while under the influence or
talking to youth inappropriately. Director stated it was an issue
recently where staff were using their cell phones/air pods during
shift for personal calls. Director reported it was addressed with
the staff members it needed to be and a staff meeting was held to
discuss the issue.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth A reported Staff 1 always has her air pod
in and is talking on the phone with friends or family members.
Youth A described hearing Staff 1 talk about her plans after work
and going to the Wayside. Youth A stated Staff 1 frequently says
things like, “I don’t want to be here, I hate it here, or I’m tired.”
Youth A reported she feels it’s unprofessional as this is where
Youth A lives and Staff 1 is being disrespectful when she says
those things in front of the youth. Youth A denied ever seeing any
staff purchase alcohol or have concerns with a staff member
driving while under the influence. Youth A reported Staff 3
frequently comes into work smelling like marijuana. Youth A
stated she told Supervisor and Supervisor talked with Staff 3 and
wrote Staff 3 up.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth B stated staff have been “fine” and do
not talk inappropriately. Youth B reported sometimes it is staff’s
tone on how they talk with the youth. Youth B stated if youth
talked like that to staff, youth would lose points for the day. Youth
B reported she has not seen staff members on their phones.
Youth B denied seeing any staff purchase alcohol or drive under
the influence. Youth B reported Staff 3 comes to work smelling
like marijuana. Youth B stated she has never seen Staff 3 use
marijuana.
5

Staff 1 and Staff 2 were interviewed face to face at the facility
on October 4, 2023, separately. They both stated a couple of
months ago staff being on their phones was an issue, but it was
addressed in a staff meeting and with the staff members that were
using their phones. They both denied staff being on their phones
as being an issue any longer. Staff 1 stated she has heard staff
say they are tired today but nothing negative toward the youth.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 denied any youth coming to them with concerns
about what staff are saying. Staff 1 and Staff 2 denied see any
staff member purchase alcohol or drive youth while under the
influence. They both denied smelling marijuana on Staff 3 or any
youth saying Staff 3 smelled of marijuana.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth C reported staff she has seen staff
members on their phones but not recently. Youth C stated she
thinks staff got in trouble for using their phones because now they
are not allowed to have their phones. Youth C stated staff treat
youth unfairly all the time. Youth C reported Supervisor, Staff 1
and Staff 2 say they “don’t want to be here, don’t like it here and
swear at youth all the time.” Youth C reported youth are not
allowed to say things like that without getting redirected by staff.
Youth C denied seeing any staff purchase alcohol or drive under
the influence with youth. Youth C reported Staff 3 comes into
work high and smells of marijuana. Youth C stated she knows
Staff 3 has been high at work because Youth C asked Staff 3 and
Staff 3 said, “you know it girl.” Youth C stated she knows what it
is like to be high and Staff 3 acts like she is high. Youth C denied
telling any staff member her concerns about Staff 3.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth D reported Staff 1 was on her air pod
today when she picked up the youths from school. Youth D stated
Staff 1 talks on her air pod “a lot.” Youth D denied seeing any
other staff be on their phones. Youth D reported Supervisor and
Staff 3 can be grumpy. Youth D described Supervisor and Staff 3
saying they are tired or don’t want to be here. Youth D denied
seeing any staff purchase alcohol or drive under the influence with
youth. Youth D reported Staff 3 has come into work high and
smelling like marijuana. Youth D stated she could tell Staff 3 was
high because how her eyes looked and how she was doing
different things. Youth D denied telling any staff member about
her concerns with Staff 3.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth E reported Supervisor and Staff 3 use
6

their phones for personal calls frequently. Youth E stated
Supervisor was talking with his mother the other day and had the
call on speaker. Youth E reported Staff 3 uses her air pod to talk
on the phone. Youth E stated Staff 3 was talking on her air pod
today when she picked up the youths from school. Youth E stated
staff can be disrespectful to youths. Youth E reported Staff 1 will
tell the youth, “It’s too early today to start this shit.” Youth E stated
sometimes the staff swear and it is a trigger to her. Youth E
denied staff swearing at youth but just in general conversation
when staff are upset. Youth E denied seeing any staff purchase
alcohol or drive under the influence with youth. Youth E stated
she did not think staff and youth ever go anywhere that sells
alcohol.
Youth F was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth F reported prior staff used to be on their
phones, but they no longer work at the facility. Youth F denied
seeing any staff recently be on their phones. Youth F denied
hearing or seeing staff members be rude or talk inappropriately to
youths. Youth F denied seeing any staff purchase alcohol or drive
under the influence with youth. Youth F reported she does not
know what marijuana smells like or what it looks like if a person is
high so would not know if a staff member smelled like marijuana
or was high at work.
AFA was interviewed via telephone on October 6, 2023. AFA
stated staff members being on their phone with personal calls was
an issue, but it was addressed by administration. AFA reported
she had not heard it was an issue anymore. AFA denied being
aware of any staff member purchasing alcohol or drive under the
influence with youth. AFA stated she was aware youths were
saying Staff 3 smelled like marijuana, but AFA stated she never
saw Staff 3 high at work or smell of marijuana.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on October 10, 2023.
Staff 3 reported staff members cannot have their cell phones on
shift anymore. Staff 3 reported a couple of months ago it was an
issue staff were using their phones and administration addressed
the issue. Staff 3 denied hearing any staff member make
inappropriate comments, saying they don’t want to be at the
facility or that they are tired. Staff 3 stated she has not had any
youth tell her staff members are saying these comments. Staff 3
denied being aware of any staff member purchasing alcohol or
drive youth while under the influence. Staff 3 denied coming into
work high or smelling like marijuana while at work. Staff 3 stated
7

she was not aware why youth would be saying that Staff 3 was
high at work and smelled of marijuana.
Documents Reviewed:
• New Hope Use of Cellular Telephone policy: “Use of
personal cellular telephone during working hours or on
company premises is subject to restrictions and may
subject the employee to corrective action, up to and
including termination.”
• Youth Opportunity Employee Handbook Standards of
Conduct: “Staff are always expected to maintain ethical and
professional behavior. This includes the expectation that
staff are to interact with youth in a manner promoting their
emotional and physical safety while incorporating trauma
responsive practices. Examples of rule infractions or
misconduct include fighting or threatening violence in the
workplace, behavior that is unprofessional, unethical, or
abusive.”
• New Hope Substance Abuse policy: “Being under the
influence of illegal drugs, alcohol, or substances of abuse
on Company property is prohibited.”
• Supervisor’s personnel file: There were write ups in
Supervisor’s file for not following the electronic policy and
not having staff get off their phones during their shift.
• Staff 3’s personnel file: There were three write ups for Staff
3 engaged in personal phone calls during shift and one for
lacking professionalism with youth.
• Staff 4’s personnel file: There was one write up for
engaging in personal phone calls during Staff 4’s shift.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as staff were using their
phone or air pods to make personal calls while on shift. Interviews
with youths and staff also indicate phones being used by staff
during the shift was occurring.
Technical Assistance:
The facility should review professional boundaries including what
staff say and discussed how youth could perceive the comments,
“I don’t want to be here, I hate it here and I’m tired” as negative
and a put down to the youth.
It was recommended Director talk with Staff 3 about the youths
believing Staff 3 is high and coming into work smelling like
marijuana.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SI2023C0000667SI dated 09/13/23; CAP pending approval
8

SIR2022C0116033 dated 7/7/2022, CAP Approved 7/22/2022
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-child
Description ratio formula for direct care workers. If a child caring institution is
contracted by the department to care for youth, the facility will
follow its contracted ratio.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are not working within ratio. Staff don't allow youth to do
anything on the weekends.
Investigation Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Supervisor denied ever being out of ratio while
he was working on shift. Supervisor stated he has heard the
youth say they did not go anywhere over the weekend because
staff did not want to. Supervisor stated sometimes youth want to
go places and some of the youths do not have privileges to go off
campus so an outing may not take place because the facility has
to stay within ratio.
Youth A and Youth B were interviewed face to face at the
facility on October 4, 2023, separately. They both denied the
facility ever being out of ratio. Youth A stated there are currently 6
youth at the facility and there are always two to three staff
working. Youth A and Youth B described going out to eat, going
to the fair, attending a parade and football game or shopping as
some of the outings. Youth A stated staff take the youths on
activities as long as the youth can leave the facility and there are
enough staff.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were interviewed face to face at the facility
on October 4, 2023, separately. They both denied ever being
out of ratio. Staff 2 stated there are always three staff on shift.
Staff 2 described one staff as being a float to cover breaks and
help with youth if need be. Both staff stated the youths go on
outings regularly.
Youth C, Youth D, and Youth F were interviewed face to face
at the facility on October 4, 2023, separately. All the youth
denied the facility being out of ratio. All the youth reported there
had to be one staff working for every three youth. Youth C and
Youth F stated sometimes they cannot go anywhere because
some youths are on pause and cannot leave the facility. Youth C,
Youth D, and Youth F described leaving the facility to get haircuts,
going to the Novi Fair, going to Island Park, attending church
services and going out to eat.
9

Youth E was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth E reported there was one time the facility
was out of ratio, but she could not recall the date. Youth E stated
Staff 1 took four youth to Dairy Queen. Youth E reported at first
there was only going to be three youth that could leave the facility,
but it ended up being four youth. Youth E stated she could not
recall when this occurred or what youths went to Dairy Queen.
AFA was interviewed via telephone on October 6, 2023. AFA
denied the facility ever being out of ratio. AFA stated there are
planned outings for the youth but sometimes not all the youth can
leave the facility, so outings need to change. AFA reported the
youths come up with the outings they would like to go on.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on October 10, 2023.
Staff 3 denied the facility ever being out of ratio. Staff 3 stated
staff get mandated to work because there is a lack of staff, but
they are always in ratio. Staff 3 reported the youths go on many
outings outside of the facility and the youths are part of deciding
where they go for an outing.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth Opportunities 2nd Shift Assignments for September
and October 2023. The assignments list what staff were
working and what youth were at the facility and any activity
that occurred. There were no assignments listed showing
the facility was out of ratio. The assignments listed outings
as: “4 youth to park with two staff, one youth back with
staff; youth preparing for bbq; 5 youth with two staff to the
library; 5 youth with two staff to skating rink; 5 youth and
two staff back from outing; three youth transition into bed;
Homecoming parade, football game, Homecoming Dance,
ice cream and Island Park 8 youth, 3 staff.”
• September and October staff schedules: Shows staff within
ratio.
• Youth placement sheet: Lists what youth at facility and
when entered care showing staff within ratio.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as staff and youth interviews
indicate the facility is within ratio. Activity logs show how many
youths are at the facility on any given day and what staff are
working. The activity logs reviewed did not show the facility out of
ratio. The facility logs show multiple off-site activities for youths.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
10

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4132 Grievance procedures.
Section (4) An agency shall provide a grievant with a written copy of the
Description grievance resolution.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are not addressing youth grievances.
Investigation Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Supervisor reported Director checks the
grievance box daily and uses a grievance tracker to document the
grievances and how they are handled. Supervisor stated Director
meets with the youth to discuss the grievances. Supervisor
denied hearing any youth say grievances are not being discussed.
Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Director stated she checks the grievance box
every morning when coming on shift and throughout the day.
Director reported when a youth fills out a grievance form the youth
signs and dates the form and places the form in the grievance
box. Director stated she follows up with every youth who fills out a
grievance form and goes over the youth’s concern. Director
reported sometimes what the youth writes on the grievance form
is more a right to speak issue or a question than it is a grievance.
Director stated she talks with the youth, writes the outcome on the
form, and signs the form, but does not always have the youth sign
and date the grievance form again. Director is not aware of any
youth grievances not being addressed.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth A reported filing four grievances in the
last month but only one of them being addressed. Youth A stated
one of the grievances was for a staff member, she could not
remember who, sharing HIPAA information and Director took care
of the situation. Youth A reported AFA spoke with Youth A about
the other grievances having to do with needing clothes and
hygiene products. Youth A stated she was not aware if other
youth have filed grievances.
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth F were interviewed
face to face at the facility on October 4, 2023, separately.
None of the youths reported filing grievances. All of the youths
described Director checking the grievance box and being the
person to talk with youth about a grievance.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 4, 2023. Youth E reported she filed a grievance and
11

Director talked with her about the grievance. Youth E denied not
having grievances being addressed.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were interviewed face to face at the facility
on October 4, 2023, separately. They both stated Director and
AFA handle the grievances filed by the youth. They both denied
hearing youth say grievances are not being addressed. Staff 2
reported some of the youths are not happy with the response they
are given regarding their grievance.
AFA was interviewed via telephone on October 6, 2023. AFA
stated Director checks the grievance box and discusses the
grievance with youths. AFA reported she would talk with youth
about client needs requests and document the solution.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on October 10, 2023.
Staff 3 reported Director checks the grievance box and handles
the grievances with youth. Staff 3 denied ever hearing from youth
that their grievances are not being addressed.
Documents Reviewed
• Grievance Tracker for July, August, September, and
October 2023. There were two grievances in July signed
and dated by youths, zero grievances in August and
October, and one in September signed and dated by Youth
A.
• Grievance Form for Youth A dated 9/25/23: Grievance for
asking to take a Covid test and having to wait until the next
morning to take a test because the facility was out of tests.
Grievance was signed and dated (9/26/23) by Youth A and
Director with listed outcome on grievance.
• Client Needs Request Form from Youth A dated 9/25/23:
Youth A requesting to get a job, socks and different
deodorant and face wipes. AFA signed and dated the form.
• Grievance Form for Youth E dated 7/11/23: Grievance
stated Youth E has not been allowed to shave. Form
signed and dated (7/11/23) by Youth E and Director with
listed outcome on grievance.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as interviews with staff and
youth indicate grievances are addressed by Director. Youth A and
Youth E both filed grievances. The grievance forms documented
Director followed up with both Youth A and Youth E and
addressed their grievances.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
12

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
